title: France and Germany pledge to fight Facebook’s Libra
text:
Facebook's proposed Libra virtual currency has been met with strong regulatory skepticism | Denis Charlet/AFP via Getty Images France and Germany pledge to fight Facebook’s Libra The two countries say they’ll fight the tech giant’s attempt to ‘claim monetary power.’

HELSINKI — France and Germany on Friday threw cold water on Facebook’s plans to launch a virtual currency, saying they would combat any effort by the company to “claim monetary power.”

“France and Germany consider that the Libra project, as set out in Facebook’s blueprint, fails to convince that those risks will be properly addressed,” Paris and Berlin wrote a joint-statement at the Ecofin gathering in Helsinki. "We believe that no private entity can claim monetary power, which is inherent to the sovereignty of Nations.”

France’s finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, used the occasion to reiterate his opposition to Libra, which the social media giant plans to launch next year for its 2.6 billion users.

“We should refuse the development of Libra in Europe,” Le Maire said on the sidelines of a gathering in Helsinki, where EU finance ministers met for two days of informal talks on climate change and capital markets.

“I think it’s wiser to think about a public digital currency and to think about the measures that the European banks might adopt to [address] the cost and the delays of international transactions,” he added.

Facebook’s plans have spooked policymakers and regulators around the world, especially as the social media behemoth plans to launch Libra next year.

Finance ministers from G7 countries in July raised a series of concerns about the looming payment service, such as money laundering, terrorist financing, financial stability and data protection.

Brussels is probing Libra to figure out how to best regulate it. France and Germany are taking a harder line.
description: The two countries say they’ll fight the tech giant’s attempt to ‘claim monetary power.’
